data.text: The theory and practice of navigating, especially the charting of a course for a ship or aircraft.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Travel or traffic by vessels, especially commercial shipping.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The act of navigating; the act of moving on water in ships or other vessels; sailing: as, the navigation of the northern seas; also, by extension, the act of “sailing” through the air in a balloon (see aërial navigation, below).
The science or art of directing the course of vessels as they sail from one part of the world to another.

An artificial waterway, or a part of a natural waterway that has been made navigable; a canal. Also <internalXref urlencoded="navvy">navvy</internalXref>. See <internalXref urlencoded="navvy">navvy</internalXref>.
The act of navigating; the act of passing on water in ships or other vessels; the state of being navigable.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: The science or art of conducting ships or vessels from one place to another, including, more especially, the method of determining a ship's position, course, distance passed over, etc., on the surface of the globe, by the principles of geometry and astronomy.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: The management of sails, rudder, etc.; the mechanics of traveling by water; seamanship.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
